In our research, we found that, no, 18 million illegal immigrants did not receive a check from the government in the middle of the closure. Here's how we know that. First, the study conducted by the Pew Research Center in November 2018 made the total number of illegal immigrants in the United States well below 18 million. In 2016, the latest available data, the report found that the number of undocumented migrants living in the country had fallen to 10.7 million, from a peak of 12.2 million in 2007. The mathematical error may have arisen from the combination of the number of legal immigrants in the equation. According to a report issued in December 2018 by the Centre for Migration Studies, 63 per cent of non-citizens ' households use social welfare programmes. However, according to census data, only half of non-citizens ' households consist of undocumented migrants. Among the remaining persons in this group are long-term temporary visitors such as foreign guest workers and students, as well as permanent residents who have not acquired citizenship but hold green cards, and there are also legal restrictions on migrants ' access to most federal benefits. Undocumented migrant households benefit primarily from government food programmes and medical aid through their children born in the United States. Unrestricted migrants are not eligible for the following federal benefits: Supplementary Nutrition Assistance Programme, formerly known as the Food Stamps Programme, non-emergency medical aid, supplementary insurance income, temporary assistance for needy families and their precursors, and assistance to families with dependent children, in accordance with the National Centre for Migration Law. Another report by the Centre for Migration Studies, which prefers low levels of migration, estimated that 4 per cent of households headed by illegal immigrants in the country used housing programmes in 2012. "while households headed by illegal immigrants use some housing and cash programmes, their use is less than that of households headed by a citizen for such programmes," the study said. Our Facebook article claims that 18 million illegal immigrants received a government check this month, while federal workers remain unpaid amid the closure of the government. We have not been able to find any evidence to support this figure, and the multiple reports place the total number of undocumented migrants living in the United States well below 18 million. Furthermore, illegal migrants are denied most federal benefits and will benefit primarily from food and medical aid programmes through their children born in the United States.
